section.title: Introduction to Annuities with Payments in Arithmetic Progression
section.p: Earlier in the chapter we studied annuities whose payments were in geometric progression (i.e. grew or declined by a constant percentage). Now we pivot to payments in arithmetic progression (i.e. grow or decline by a constant absolute amount).

The present value of an annuity with n payments, starting with a payment of K and whose payments grow by K per period is written K(Ia)_{\angln \iota} where \iota is the effective periodic interest rate. Such an annuity is called an increasing annuity immediate.

figure.caption: Timeline for an increasing annuity immediate.
figure.image: A timeline with K at 1, 2K at 2, up to nK at n. The present value of an increasing annuity with first payment K is labeled at time 0.

section.p: The future value of an annuity with n payments which decrease by K per period and whose last payment is K is written K(Ds)_{\angln \iota}. Such an annuity is called a decreasing annuity immediate.

figure.caption: Timeline for a decreasing annuity immediate.
figure.image: A timeline with K at n, 2K at n-1, up to nK at 1. The present value of a decreasing annuity with last payment K is labeled at time 0.

task.p: Olga buys a 5-year increasing annuity for X. Olga will receive 2 at the end of the first month, 4 at the end of the second month, and for each month thereafter the payment increases by 2. The nominal interest rate is 9\% convertible quarterly. Calculate X.

A perpetuity costs 77.1 and makes annual payments at the end of the year. The perpetuity pays 1 at the end of year 2, 2 at the end of year 3, ..., n at the end of year (n+1). After year (n+1), the payments remain constant at n. The effective annual interest rate is 10.5\%. Calculate n.

Louis is supposed to be given a monthly gift of 50 at the end of each month throughout the year. By August, the donor is no longer able to keep up these payments, and the payments decline by 10 each month, with the payment in September set at 40, and so on until the end of the year.
Louis remains grateful, and deposits each payment into an account with \iota^{(12)} = 9\%. Find the amount in the account immediately after the last payment at the end of December.

Kara makes deposits of 1000 into a primary account at the end of each year for 5 years. Clark makes deposits of 1000 into a primary account at the beginning of each year for 5 years. Each year, just after interest is credited to each account, they withdraw only the interest and reinvest it into a secondary account (each has their own secondary accounts). The primary account Kara uses has an effective annual interest rate of 9\% and the primary account Clark uses has an effective annual interest rate of 10\%. The secondary account used by Kara has an effective annual interest rate of 9\% and the secondary account used by Clark has an effective annual interest rate of 8\%. At the end of 5 years, Kara has a total of X and Clark has a total of Y. Calculate Y-X.
